title: The Aftermath of a YouTube Apology
description: Quantifying the lasting impact of a YouTube controversy.

slides.text: When YouTuber apology videos became Halloween costumes, we knew it was time to investigate.
slides.nerd: YouTube video of the DIY Halloween costume.

slides.text: All sorts of celebrities have controversies that end with public apologies. But few have to shit where they eat — so to speak — like YouTubers. Plus, thereâ€™s data ðŸ¤“.
We researched nearly every possible popular YouTuber with a documented controversy in the past few years and found <mark>31</mark> with apology videos.
slides.nerd: We analyzed 20,000 accounts and cross-referenced with Wikipedia, X, and Y to look for channels with controversy or apology details. We then manually vetted the results for false positives and reduced to channels with at least 90 days of subscriber data on both sides of the apology.

slides.text: <mark>Beauty YouTubers</mark> have a curiously large share of the shame pie.
What did we find? TLDR; There are a wide variety of outcomes after an apology video. Weâ€™ll focus on the <mark>eight YouTubers</mark> from the overrepresented beauty community.
<mark>Step One</mark> To measure impact we can look at how their channel subscriptions (subs) grew, starting with their pre-controversy trajectory. Where were they headed?
We compare their daily total subs to their pre-controversy max. As expected, nearly all channels were gaining subs.
Steeper lines means faster growth. <mark class=non>Jake Paul</mark> more than doubled his subs in the three months prior to his controversy.
<mark>Step Two</mark> What was the effect on their sub rate after they released their apology?
